awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Shock Tube Study of Laminar Flames in Transportation Fuels at Engine Relevant Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop novel experimental techniques for studying flames at conditions relevant to transportation systems. Currently, experimental limitations prevent the study of premixed flames at the high-temperatures found in modern spark-ignition and jet engines. By using shock tubes, this work aims to overcome those practical limits and allow future experimental studies to be conducted at the conditions most relevant to modern engines. Exploratory work will also be undertaken to understand unique structures only present in high-temperature flames. Together, this work will support the development of the clean and efficient engines needed to meet the critical goals of reducing air pollution, reigning in transportation-related greenhouse gas emissions, and limiting dependence on foreign fossil fuels.
 
The first of two major goals of this project is to refine the shock-tube flame speed method recently demonstrated in the Hanson laboratory. The rapid heating and quiescent post-shock conditions in a shock tube allow for spherically expanding flames to be initiated and studied at previously inaccessible temperatures. This method will be further refined and validated to optimize experimental and data-processing methods in order to ensure that high-temperature flame data produced using the method meets the high quality standards of the scientific and engineering communities. The second major goal is to use a variety of laser- and imaging-based diagnostics to study peculiar flame structures observed at high temperatures. Both simulations and preliminary experimental evidence suggest that two-stage flames, with a cool flame preceding the classical hot flame, may be observed at high temperatures. This phenomenon will be experimentally investigated, an objective that will leverage both the unique ability to generate flames at high temperatures afforded by the shock tube and the existing optical diagnostic expertise of the Hanson lab. Diagnostics to be employed in the study of high-temperature flame structure are likely to include line-of-sight laser absorption, planar laser-induced fluorescence, and spectrally filtered emission imaging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Laminar flame speed is a critical combustion parameter that contains thermodynamic, transport, and chemical-kinetic information about a fuel/oxidizer mixture. For this reason, laminar flame speed is often a popular target for the validation and refinement of chemical kinetic models. Additionally, numerical modeling of complex engine combustion processes frequently requires the laminar flame speed as an input parameter to minimize computational cost. Therefore, it is of critical importance to have an accurate database of laminar flame speeds for transportation fuels at engine-relevant conditions. However, very few experimental measurements of laminar flame speed exist at unburned-gas temperatures exceeding 750 K, due to the short autoignition timescales of practical fuels at high temperatures.

Under this project, we have successfully refined the shock-tube flame-speed method to measure laminar flame speeds at unburned-gas temperatures greater than 1,000 K. A unique, large field-of-view side-wall schlieren imaging capability was built for the circular-cross-section shock tube using a pair of custom-designed, conformal cylindrical doublet windows. The side-wall schlieren capability enabled simultaneous side-wall-schlieren and end-wall-OH*/CH*-emission imaging of flame propagation behind reflected shock waves. At high temperatures, side-wall imaging revealed distortion in the assumed spherical geometry of the expanding flames, leading to the adoption of an area-averaged linear curvature (AA-LC) model for extracting flame speed from an expanding flame front that is not perfectly spherical. In order to address non-ideal gas-dynamic effects, such as shock bifurcation behind reflected shock waves, a logistic regression analysis was performed using accumulated shock-tube flame data to identify critical experimental parameters promoting smooth flame propagation. The results show that having a low specific-heat ratio for the fuel/oxidizer mixture is the dominant cause of flame instability, leading to the adoption of a 21% O2 ? 79% Ar (referred to as airgon) oxidizer mixture in our subsequent measurements.

Accounting for the non-spherical flame morphology through side-wall schlieren imaging and using airgon as an oxidizer, measurements of atmospheric-pressure propane flame speeds were conducted at unburned-gas temperatures exceeding 1,000 K for the first time. The high-temperature propane data were compared with predictions from existing kinetic models, which revealed major disagreement in predicted laminar flame speeds, particularly at high temperatures. This work highlights the value of the new measurements performed under the present project and demonstrates the need for kinetic model validation at engine-relevant, high-temperature conditions. With the successful demonstration of propane flame speed measurements, we further surveyed the high-temperature laminar flame speeds of primary reference fuels (PRFs) n-heptane and iso-octane ? components frequently used as gasoline surrogates. From the experimental data, we found that the widely used power-law flame speed correlation performs poorly when extrapolating low-temperature flame speeds to higher, engine-relevant temperatures; this deficiency led to the proposition of a new, non-Arrhenius flame speed correlation that better characterizes the trend of high-temperature flame speeds.

Under the present grant, novel diagnostics were also developed and used to observe the behavior of high-temperature flames behind reflected shock waves. For example, the observation of flame drift led to the development of the flame image velocimetry (FIV) method, which provided measurements of flow velocity in the post-reflected-shock region.

Outcomes from this project have the potential to significantly impact combustion science, as laminar flame speed measurements at high temperatures allow for the development of refined models that can be used to design and optimize new energy systems. These next-generation processes and devices are expected to promote sustainability by having improved efficiencies and extended flexibility to accommodate alternative, carbon-neutral fuels.


Last Modified: 02/28/2023
Modified by: Ronald K Hanson
